name: NewYorker
text: “No matter how many times you see it pulled off, the magic trick is always a surprise: how a text that is hundreds or thousands of years old turns out to be about the thing that’s happening to you.” @BananaKarenina on revisiting “Oedipus” under lockdown. https://t.co/t8QHt3AWME

name: NewYorker
text: Most accounts of Hurricane Katrina begin when the levees broke and conclude not long after. "But these stories have a denuded sense of what happened, why, or what might have prevented the catastrophe," Andy Horowitz writes in "Katrina." https://t.co/MT0f4nMhdS
